title: American_Top_40_1979_October_20th
description:
"We're counting down the most popular hits in the nation, from Goose Egg, Wyoming to Chicken, Alaska; from Eagle Rock, Virginia to Pelican Rapids, Minnesota."


American Top 40 with Casey Kasem aired on radio from July 4, 1970 until August 6, 1988. This is a recording of a rebroadcast from internet radio.

This is the last three hours of a four hour show. I supplied the eight missing songs. If you don't want to play them, skip all the files that start with double zero.

In this broadcast:

One singer/song writer in the countdown is the youngest person ever to receive an honorary doctorate degree in music from Princeton University.

Casey tells us whatever happened to Jan and Dean.

There is a song in the countdown that features the largest group of musicians to hit the chart since the Mormon Tabernacle Choir.

A listener wants to know, "What American recording artist has been the most successful in the 70's?" I would never have guessed the answer to this one.

One song in the top ten gets there by moving up an incredible 28 places!

In 1968, a long established recording star finally hit number one for the first time and that number one record was the last time he was able to make the top 40 for eleven years. This week, the hit that ended that famine is in the top ten.
